body.p: First make sure your date and time is set correctly using date MMDDhhmmYYYY. Use UTC time.

pre.caption: Set the date and UTC time

body.pre:
(Check the clock) livecd gentoo # date Mon Mar 6 00:14:13 UTC 2006
(Set the current date and time if required) livecd gentoo # date 030600162006 (Format is MMDDhhmmYYYY) Mon Mar 6 00:16:00 UTC 2006
body.p: Next, download a stage from one of our mirrors:
body.pre:
livecd gentoo # links http://www.gentoo.org/main/en/mirrors.xml (Pick a mirror, move to the releases/x86/current-stage3/ directory, highlight the stage3 of your choice, probably the i686 stage3, and press D to download it)
(Or download it directly with wget without choosing a nearby mirror) livecd gentoo # wget ftp://distfiles.gentoo.org/pub/gentoo/releases/x86/current-stage3/stage3-i686-*.tar.bz2
body.p: Go to /mnt/gentoo and unpack the stage using tar xjpf <stage3 tarball>.
body.pre:
livecd gentoo # time tar xjpf stage3*
real 1m14.157s user 1m2.920s sys 0m7.530s

body.p: Mount the /proc, /dev, and /sys file systems, copy over the /etc/resolv.conf file, then chroot into your Gentoo environment.
body.pre: livecd usr # cd / livecd / # mount -t proc proc /mnt/gentoo/proc livecd / # mount --rbind /dev /mnt/gentoo/dev livecd / # mount --rbind /sys /mnt/gentoo/sys livecd / # cp -L /etc/resolv.conf /mnt/gentoo/etc/ livecd / # chroot /mnt/gentoo /bin/bash livecd / # source /etc/profile
body.p: Fetch the latest portage snapshot from the mirrors using emerge-webrsync.

pre.caption: Running emerge-webrsync to install a Portage snapshot

body.p: Set your time zone information by using the correct listing in /usr/share/zoneinfo.
body.pre:
livecd / # ls /usr/share/zoneinfo (Using Brussels as an example) livecd / # cp /usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Brussels /etc/localtime livecd / # echo "Europe/Brussels" > /etc/timezone
livecd / # date Wed Mar 8 00:46:05 CET 2006

body.p: Choose your profile using eselect. This is an example of the output you might see.
body.pre: livecd / # eselect profile list Available profile symlink targets: [1] default/linux/x86/10.0 * [2] default/linux/x86/10.0/desktop [3] default/linux/x86/10.0/desktop/gnome [4] default/linux/x86/10.0/server
body.p: Choose the appropriate profile. Keep in mind that default USE flags are determined based on the profile you pick.

section.title: Set your host name and domain name

body.p: Set your host name in /etc/conf.d/hostname and /etc/hosts. In the following example, we use mybox as host name and at.myplace as domain name. You can either edit the config files with nano or use the following commands:
body.pre: livecd / # cd /etc livecd etc # echo "127.0.0.1 mybox.at.myplace mybox localhost" > hosts livecd etc # sed -i -e 's/hostname.*/hostname="mybox"/' conf.d/hostname (Use defined host name and check) livecd etc # hostname mybox livecd etc # hostname -f mybox.at.myplace
